1125022626475401217.text: RE: “Accidental plagiarism”, it’s mostly bullshit. You either didn’t know the above (and others will judge whether you should have known), you’re being careless with others’ work, or you’re willfully trying to make people believe it’s your work. (4/)

1125022624998936577.text: Citing sources is not a formalism, it’s necessary to the development of the field/practice. Your work stands on the shoulders of others, and it’s necessary to (1)acknowledge their countribution, and (2) allow others to recreate your research and learn more about prerequisites(3/)

1125022623765860356.text: ...in a talk, if it’s cited clearly on the slide, and tangential, I wouldn’t necessarily verbally cover it. You should, if the source is the subject of your discussion, or a large contributor to it. (3/)

1125022622323019776.text: In written works, I recommend a numbered list in the references section, with bracketed numbers at the end of quotes, paragraphs, usage of that material (ex. “[1]”). In a talk, I would recommend same, or an inline mention. (2/)

1125022619240140802.text: Avoiding plagiarism is easy, but requires mindfulness. There’s one rule: don’t represent, even by omission, another’s work as your own. The way you cite (inline, footnote, numeric pointer to references) isn’t as important as *doing* any one of them. (1/)

The three lanes of Russian election interference:

1) Social media trolling
2) GRU hack-and-leak
3) Direct attacks against election infrastructure

1123397841487970304.text: Part of the problem here is that all Russian activity is lumped together and assumed to be part of a well-coordinated operation. In reality, it looks like there were three lanes of Russian interference with minimal coordination between the two most visible components.

1125636249899765761.text: Writing teaser headlines about correcting false statements just helps propagate the false statement. People don’t like to read, and no headline is going to make fact checking sound exciting. Just say, clearly and up front, that the statement is false.

1125634523364872192.text: If the headline doesn’t make it clear, upfront, that a statement is a lie then the headline is just amplifying the lie. Same thing for quibbling language, “it would not be accurate to make the statement that…”

1125634197073227778.text: I cannot stress this enough — don’t write clickbait headlines when countering falsehoods. “Find out the truth behind the claim ‘polar bears love the heat’” — NO! “X lied that ‘polar bears love the heat,’ find out more”
